data.text:
Lane: We do not see big wage increases so far. But we do expect a response. What is critical is how big it will be, and we will continue to look at this

2/3

🧵Inflation will remain high at the start of 2022 but will fall later on, especially towards the end of the year, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @vzinios. Our current projections foresee inflation below our 2% target in 2023 and 2024 https://t.co/2TpIw87DAF

1/3 https://t.co/9ajhwnCvk5

Public debt instruments tend to be easier to sell in times of market stress.

A minimum public debt quota could substantially improve the resilience of money market funds in a crisis. Read more in our latest Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/qd49kRpmwg https://t.co/AN5B6P54DK

It also discusses the impact of a mandatory public debt quota on private debt money market funds. How could it boost their shock-absorbing capacity and what are the associated costs and benefits? 

Read more https://t.co/NpG94x4aRn
2/2

🧵What can be done to tackle the vulnerabilities of money market funds?

Our Macroprudential Bulletin looks at policies to address the liquidity risk of these funds and at how they might strengthen their resilience against large and unexpected outflows https://t.co/NpG94x4aRn
1/2 https://t.co/G0Bd8FcTDY
Account of the monetary policy meeting of the Governing Council of the ECB on 15-16 December 2021 https://t.co/2u5OpIJ3HY

Watch live from 11:00 CET: Vice-President Luis de Guindos talks at @Bruegel_org about non-performing loans and lessons learned from past financial crises that can help us weather the current pandemic scenario⬇️ https://t.co/JH1REAN5Ti

Congratulations to our colleague Eva Murciano, who will take the helm of the ECB’s Human Resources department from 1 February 2022.

We look forward to working together with Eva in her new role!

Press release: https://t.co/XB459WepFz https://t.co/ZiZl4OiTdN

Meet @drkaenzig. He won our 2021 Young Economist Prize for his research on the economic consequences of carbon pricing.
Interested in presenting your own work at this year’s #ECBForum and the chance to win €10,000? Then submit your paper by 13 February https://t.co/pfedqyh8CZ https://t.co/bdVpDOKJ0s
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Nov 2021) https://t.co/6R2YibGDJb

Did you miss our building being lit up to mark the 20th anniversary of euro cash?

Turn the sound up for this one 🎶

#EUROat20 https://t.co/zFsmeiDtl8

Unsere Geldpolitik wird allein von unserem Mandat der Preisstabilität geleitet, sagt Direktoriumsmitglied @Isabel_Schnabel der Süddeutschen Zeitung @sz. Sie kann nur erfolgreich sein, wenn die Bevölkerung uns vertraut. 

Das ganze Interview https://t.co/DJg99zSEUN https://t.co/E9u2FtIdr0

Our monetary policy is guided solely by our price stability mandate, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel tells Süddeutsche Zeitung @sz. It can only succeed if people trust us. 

Read the full interview https://t.co/BpOHPZBIaD https://t.co/wFA5gYB6i0

How do we address climate change? Executive Board member @FrankElderson and Irene Heemskerk, who heads our Climate Change Centre, met with civil society organisations to discuss how we integrate environmental considerations into what we do https://t.co/sGHoJF1gAz https://t.co/J2j3IggCC7

Lagarde: we can use this opportunity to turn our achievements into lasting progress for Europe in three key directions:

▶️Providing stability
▶️Strengthening the supply side of the economy
▶️Ensuring Europe’s strategic autonomy

Read the full speech https://t.co/uE7nUNmL66
2/2

🧵We are emerging from the crisis stronger, but the task now is to embed the lessons we have learnt, President @Lagarde tells national parliamentarians at the European affairs discussion forum, COSAC https://t.co/uE7nUNmL66
1/2

The €STR remains a reliable benchmark that accurately reflects how much banks must pay when borrowing overnight cash without collateral from financial counterparties. We assessed its methodology, scope and calibration in our Annual Methodology Review https://t.co/GM2myeO570 https://t.co/5MWuPsF1kB

Hakkarainen: Banks are well trusted and customer loyalty is still strong. Technological developments cannot be seen as something new. Bank customers have been moving from traditional branch-based banking to online and mobile alternatives for some decades now.

3/3

Hakkarainen: Technological progress come with risks. Greater reliance on technology and third parties, including outsourcing and cloud computing, makes banks more dependent on IT services and more vulnerable to cyber risk.

2/3

🧵 Many fintechs offer financial services in collaboration with banks, says Supervisory Board member Pentti Hakkarainen. We must preserve financial stability and prudential soundness, while allowing for IT innovation https://t.co/TRjyDicpfe

1/3 https://t.co/7uJZjx0LzW
Economic Bulletin box: Fiscal policies in 2022 – implications from the 2022 draft budgetary plans https://t.co/ydu4fOJvoq
Economic Bulletin box: Liquidity conditions and monetary policy operations from 28 July to 2 November 2021 https://t.co/laS4AySSxX
Economic Bulletin box: Decomposing market-based measures of inflation compensation into inflation expectations and risk premia https://t.co/uQC7jaBkdo
Economic Bulletin box: Financing conditions through the lens of euro area companies https://t.co/c5ZjxzkMfP

The outlook is uncertain and depends on pandemic developments, containment measures and consumer demand. The situation is likely to remain difficult this year 

3/3

Supply chain disruptions are affecting global economic activity, trade and prices. Since October 2020 they have caused global industrial production and trade outside the euro area to decline by around 1.4% and 2.7% respectively

2/3

🧵Suppliers have been struggling to fulfil increasing orders due to difficulties in the transportation sector, pandemic-related restrictions and labour shortages. How does this affect the global economy?https://t.co/CjzxIdD4kb #EconomicBulletin
1/3 https://t.co/dXlyzEzonS
Economic Bulletin article: The ECB Survey of Monetary Analysts - an introduction https://t.co/ihJ0OCGkf8

The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more https://t.co/WseKamtyhX https://t.co/ba459Ns89Q

Euro banknotes and coins have 20 candles on their birthday cake this year 💶

We’re twelve days into the new year, but the celebrations aren’t over just yet! Check out our #EUROat20 web page for a slice of the action 🍰https://t.co/8kFEVlejXJ https://t.co/gMNqJiJZx4

Enria: Some banks are already taking digital transformation as an opportunity to improve efficiency. But the climate crisis exposes them to risks which they need to be ready to manage – banks have progressed on this but none are close to meeting our supervisory expectations
3/3

Enria: Beyond Basel, we welcome the changes in the European Commission’s Banking Package 2021, for example in environmental, social and governance risks and in assessing whether members of a bank’s management body are, individually and collectively, fit and proper
2/3

🧵The Basel standards are the cornerstone of financial stability and provide a level playing field in global banking, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Any deviation would weaken EU resilience and the credibility of the banking sector https://t.co/HPUIWoG8J1
1/3 https://t.co/ABYytS8qd7
Occasional Paper: Global value chains - Measurement, trends and drivers https://t.co/M36LJM5DFt

Are you interested in finding out more about central bank communication? Read also our #EconomicBulletin on how we communicate on the economic outlook and how our approach compares with the one of the @federalreserve and the @bankofengland  https://t.co/gORXfqdTDG

5/5

Following our strategy review, we decided to modernise our monetary policy communication and make it more accessible. Our findings show a clear step change, with the ECB’s latest policy communication having become more understandable 

4/5 https://t.co/6aaBalHC2S

Our findings show that while most people know of the ECB, their interest in us and knowledge of what we do is relatively limited. So we need to make our communication simpler and relate it more to people’s lives

3/5 https://t.co/pct9TFFtGZ

When reaching out to the wider public, we at the ECB need to consider the diversity of the euro area. We communicate to 340 million people in 24 languages. Within and across countries, financial literacy, inflation expectations and trust in the ECB vary considerably 

2/5

🧵How central banks communicate matters, to markets and experts and also to the wider public. By influencing inflation expectations, good communication makes monetary policy more effective. It also helps hold central banks to account https://t.co/9WJNOuUnUw #EconomicBulletin

1/5 https://t.co/xQCvVAulKY
Euro area securities issues statistics (Nov 2021) https://t.co/IWoVaq8RXk

Porgiamo le nostre più sentite condoglianze ai familiari, agli amici e ai colleghi di David Sassoli.
Comunicato stampa https://t.co/65hsOTJrZP
2/2

Esprimiamo il nostro cordoglio per la scomparsa di David Sassoli, Presidente del Parlamento europeo, che ha lavorato con instancabile dedizione per un’Europa più unita e socialmente consapevole. Ci mancheranno la sua gentilezza e umiltà 1/2 https://t.co/heOVNh6ii3

We send our condolences to Mr Sassoli’s family and to his friends and colleagues.
Press release https://t.co/65hsOTJrZP
2/2

We express our condolences following the death of European Parliament President David Sassoli.

Mr Sassoli was a dedicated European who worked tirelessly for a more united and socially conscious Europe. His kindness and humility will be missed.
1/2 https://t.co/0qSsmBTEKY

Lagarde: We understand that rising prices are a concern for many people, and we take that concern very seriously. But people can trust that our commitment to price stability is unwavering.

Read the full remarks https://t.co/xeJ4Rxc1ZH 

3/3

Lagarde: With this strategy, we are well placed to continue ensuring price stability in this fast-changing world.

And that is especially important today in light of the phase of higher inflation we are seeing

2/3

🧵Speaking at a ceremony marking the change of office of the President of the @Bundesbank, President Christine @Lagarde reflects on the conclusion of the #ECBStrategyReview last year

https://t.co/xeJ4Rxc1ZH

1/3

Household net worth increased at an annual rate of 6.6% in the third quarter of 2021. This growth was driven largely by valuation gains in assets and financial investment. These gains exceeded the increase in liabilities. Press release https://t.co/zfKc5HeoD8 https://t.co/zrFGGSatlX
Occasional Paper: Towards a single fiscal performance indicator https://t.co/JtuKQVTwSM
Working Paper: Savings, efficiency and the nature of bank runs https://t.co/supUBO9jm4

Supply-chain disruptions led to an estimated 2.6% drop in euro area industrial production between October 2020 and September 2021. The effects of these bottlenecks are expected to persist in the short term https://t.co/AutILrOaI6 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/i1aRjPUCdL
Euro money market statistics (7th maintenance period 2021) https://t.co/u4s6jb9jF8
Euro area quarterly balance of payments and international investment position (Q3 2021) https://t.co/TgYDjV3aiz

Lane: The central element in understanding underlying inflation is to find out what happens to the trend in wages. We will be looking at wage settlements throughout the year  

4/4

Lane: The pandemic makes it more difficult to interpret underlying inflation. It will take some time to filter out the effects of the pandemic, such as base effects or supply bottlenecks, and have a proper assessment of what’s going on with underlying inflation 

3/4

Lane: The data we have make it quite unlikely that the criteria we set to raise interest rates will be fulfilled this year. To raise rates, we need to see sufficient progress in underlying inflation 

2/4

🧵Pandemic-related special factors led to unusually low inflation in 2020 and unusually high inflation in 2021, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @sole24ore. 2022 is a transition phase: high inflation will be fading this year https://t.co/AKO9UUXnAE

1/4 https://t.co/1e0chsJhyx

Enria: Regulatory obstacles should be removed to ensure a more integrated management of capital within the banking union. Banks could rely on branches rather than subsidiaries, as it’s a pity that third-country groups are making better use of the Single Market than European banks

🧵 We prefer the faithful and timely implementation of Basel III without any deviations, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria tells @LesEchos. Too many exceptions can add multiple cracks in the dyke so that the whole structure becomes more fragile. https://t.co/KZzlxZkzmb
1/2 https://t.co/s0ROB0cHkD

Latest labour market developments show that imbalances between labour demand and supply are causing market rigidity. While in the US this is translating into rising wages, this is not as prevalent in the UK https://t.co/pjUGXTFfhN #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/avflzlZgqq

Tonight is your last chance to see our main building lit up for the 20th anniversary of euro banknotes and coins.
 
If you’re in Frankfurt, make sure you come to #Ostend and take in this beautiful sight!

#EUROat20 https://t.co/A2ZVDU8nuG

The euro belongs to all of us 🇪🇺

In the last 20 years, euro banknotes and coins have become an essential part of our daily life and an anchor of stability.

#EUROat20 https://t.co/6UhcAMKIbH

The green transition may put upward pressure on inflation, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel at the @ASSAMeeting.

Monetary policy cannot afford to look through higher energy prices if they pose a risk to price stability over the medium term https://t.co/2zd1ztyDQ9 https://t.co/FVuS6eNMOJ

Listen to the full interview with @rtenews https://t.co/3mPjXsc1Fn

4/4

Monetary policy essentially works over a 18-24 month horizon.

Unless the inflation pressure is going to remain above 2% in 2023 and 2024, it would be a mistake to tighten policy in response to inflation that’s high right now

3/4

The three-year period – 2020, 2021, 2022 – is basically part of a pandemic cycle in inflation. 

The pandemic is a unique episode. In that sense, it should not be interpreted in terms of comparing to historical norms

2/4

🧵 Inflation will be coming down in 2022 following a peak at the end of 2021, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @rtenews.

We expect inflation to be a little bit below our 2% target in 2023 and 2024 https://t.co/UGpLMJ4T7e

1/4 https://t.co/PLzJJFRlBr

Euro banknotes and coins have been around for 20 years. In that time they’ve become part of our shared identity and culture.
We’re stronger together with the euro 🇪🇺

#EUROat20 https://t.co/5b5wKD8yXM
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Comín i Oliveres, Ponsatí Obiols and Puigdemont i Casamajó, MEPs, on banking supervision https://t.co/BkHb7w90Vr

The euro is our money – European unity and stability in the palms of our hands.

This year we celebrate 20 years of euro banknotes and coins being part of our daily life. 

#EUROat20 https://t.co/zERJVcWAKM
Congratulations @RaphAuer! We look forward to working together. https://t.co/2SRtPWOT5y

Watch our main building in Frankfurt light up for the 20th anniversary of euro banknotes and coins ⬇️

You can catch the light show from 18:00 CET every night until 9 January 2022.

#EUROat20 https://t.co/W7FfEbx9T9
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Nov 2021) https://t.co/6PYERmK1S9
Many thanks for sharing! We look forward to seeing the photos. https://t.co/0NgznrhRgK

The euro:
🧑‍🤝‍🧑 343 million people 
🇪🇺 19 EU countries
💶 one currency

#EUROat20 https://t.co/roP3zwNFal

We are celebrating the 20th anniversary of our single currency, the euro! 

To mark the occasion, we are illuminating our main building in Frankfurt every night until 9 January 2022

#EUROat20 https://t.co/PS8FIQYXLl

Happy New Year, and happy birthday to the euro! 20 years ago today, people in the euro area held the first euro banknotes and coins in their hands. Since then the euro has become part of our identity and culture. It builds bridges between Europeans 
https://t.co/8kFEVlejXJ https://t.co/yFHrBIRgWS

Euro banknotes and coins turn 20 tomorrow! To mark the #EUROat20 anniversary we’re illuminating our main building in Frankfurt every night until 9 January 2022 https://t.co/8kFEVlejXJ https://t.co/2aRgD49oUH
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in November? How do they compare with October's figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/WxoI9Wn95h https://t.co/nNlMRrZT8L
Working Paper: Endogenous growth, downward wage rigidity and optimal inflation https://t.co/vhsQlXwvys

Did Santa bring you new headphones? What better way to try them out than by listening to #TheECBPodcast! This year we covered topics ranging from monetary policy and financial stability to female empowerment and climate change. Tune in https://t.co/upILFNG0mO #spotifywrapped https://t.co/q4Fkav0yms

We wish you a joyful holiday season!
Our tree is from a sustainable supplier in the Spessart region of Germany, just outside Frankfurt. After the holidays, the tree will be recycled and reused as compost. https://t.co/2EPJ2i8QdG

Defined contribution pension schemes, characterised by fixed premiums and variable future benefit, grew by 5.3% in the third quarter of 2021. In the same period, defined benefit schemes, with pre-determined benefit, grew by 1.4%. Read the press release https://t.co/YjEhmWOnnz https://t.co/VxXlhxFknl

Schnabel : Nous devons conserver toutes les options ouvertes pour faire face aux nouvelles données et nous assurer d’atteindre durablement notre objectif de 2%. 

Lire l'interview complète https://t.co/otMfcVbYiV

2/2

🧵Nous avons fait un pas important vers la normalisation de notre politique monétaire mais cela doit être un processus graduel, déclare @Isabel_Schnabel, membre du directoire, à @lemondefr 

1/2 https://t.co/0qUfuCW5xX

Schnabel: We need to retain optionality to respond to new data and make sure that we sustainably reach our 2% target. 

Read full interview https://t.co/f2Xz3TH3df

2/2

🧵We have taken an important step towards the normalisation of our monetary policy but this has to be a gradual process, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel tells @lemondefr 

1/2 https://t.co/HBqdjiiE5p

Enria: After Brexit, some banks used a European corporation, the societas Europaea, to bring their business from London to the continent. The paradox is that non-European banks are making better use of the internal market and banking union than European banks.
2/2

🧵 The European Deposit Insurance Scheme is needed and will happen but it is taking too long, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria tells @FD_Nieuws. The scheme will be funded by contributions from banks so no taxpayer money will cover emerging problems https://t.co/JF2KqkhTbq
1/2 https://t.co/R52G4Cz4Tr

Firms’ plans for how to reduce their emissions, also known as forward-looking targets, and their climate disclosures are very important elements for reducing their credit risk.
Read the full paper here https://t.co/0IzVW6fa4S
2/2

🧵Firms that are better prepared for the low-carbon transition have better credit ratings and receive more favourable credit risk assessments. This is one of the findings of our latest working paper on the low-carbon transition, climate commitments and firm credit risk.
1/2 https://t.co/7avK4YBJ6l

We're looking for recent graduates with postgraduate degrees, preferably PhDs, to apply for our Economist Graduate Programme.
Catalina and Tajda are current participants and they describe the programme as inspiring and unique.
Apply here by 3 January https://t.co/Tm1DHXRiQM https://t.co/guMD2NCwZq
